p: All the essential oils isolated in different seasons exhibited DPPH radical scavenging activity in a dose-dependent manner (5 µL/mL–25 µL/mL) ( Table 5). The radical scavenging potential of ACREO and ACLEO from three altitudes in the form of their IC 50 values in four different seasons was observed as Spring: ACBTREO > ACPGLEO > ACBTLEO > ACPNLEO > ACPNREO > ACPGREO; Summer: ACPNREO > ACPGREO > ACBTREO > ACPGLEO > ACPNLEO > ACBTLEO; Autumn: ACPNREO > ACPNLEO > ACBTREO > ACPGLEO > ACBTLEO > ACPGREO; Winter: ACPNREO > ACBTREO > ACPNLEO > ACPGLEO > ACPGREO > ACBTLEO, respectively, compared to the standards, BHT (IC 50 = 28.37 µg/mL) > catechin (IC 50 = 28.48 µg/mL). The antioxidant power of EOs might be attributed to their hydrogen donating ability to DPPH free radicals.
